net.joeclark.proceduralgeneration

Class MultiOrderMarkovChain<T extends Serializable>

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.joeclark.proceduralgeneration.MultiOrderMarkovChain<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of a "state". Must be serializable so the model can be serializable.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, MarkovChain<T>

    public class MultiOrderMarkovChain<T extends Serializable>
extends Object
implements MarkovChain<T>, Serializable
    The reference implementation for net.joeclark.proceduralgeneration.MarkovChain.

    This implementation offers multi-order models with a Katz back-off. What that means is, if maxOrder is greater than 1, multiple models may match any given sequence. For example, if you provide the sequence {'J','A','V','A'}, and maxOrder==3, we will first check to see if we have a model for states that follow {'A','V','A'}. If none is found, for example because that sequence was never seen in training data, we check for a model for states that follow {'V','A'}. Failing that too, we fall back on the model of transitions from the state 'A', which is certain to exist if 'A' is a valid input to the relevant method (weightedRandomNext or unWeightedRandomNext).

    Another feature that may be desired in procedural generation applications is the option to inject some "true randomness" in the form of "prior" relative probabilities, i.e., small weights given to transitions not observed in training data. These can make up for the limitations of a training dataset and enable the generation of sequences not observed in training. Use the addPriors() method after training your model to take advantage of this.

    If multi-order models are not desired, set maxOrder to 1. If priors are not desired, do nothing; they will not be added by default.
    See Also:

        public Map<List<T>,Map<T,Double>> getModel()
        Reveals the model stored in the instance, in its raw form.
        Returns:
        A map of sequences to a map of states to weights; for each sequence, the inner map contains weights (relative probabilities) for each possible transition from the end of that sequence.

      • allKnownStates

        public Set<T> allKnownStates()
        Description copied from interface: MarkovChain
        The set of all "states" that the model is aware of. For example, if a MarkovChain<Character> is being used to generate random text, this returns the "alphabet". If a MarkovChain<String> is being used to simulate sentences, this returns the "vocabulary".
        Specified by:
        allKnownStates in interface MarkovChain<T extends Serializable>
        Returns:
        a Set of known states

      • allPossibleNext

        public Set<T> allPossibleNext(List<T> currentSequence)
        Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method provides the set of all the states that may occur next in the chain.

        This implementation offers multi-order models with a Katz back-off. What that means is, if maxOrder is greater than 1, multiple models may match your sequence. For example, if you provide the sequence {'J','A','V','A'}, and maxOrder==3, we will first check to see if we have a model for states that follow {'A','V','A'}. If none is found, we check for a model for states that follow {'V','A'}. Failing that, we fall back on the model of transitions from the state 'A'.

        Specified by:
        allPossibleNext in interface MarkovChain<T extends Serializable>
        Parameters:
        currentSequence - All states in this List must be known to the model, i.e., members of the set returned by allKnownStates().
        Returns:
        A set of states. If the last state in the currentSequence is a "terminal state", that is, a state known to occur only at the end(s) of sequence(s), the return will be an empty set.

      • weightedRandomNext

        public T weightedRandomNext(List<T> currentSequence)
        Description copied from interface: MarkovChain
        Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method chooses one state at random from the set of states that may occur next in the chain, based on a set of weights or an absolute or relative probability distribution of relative or absolute probabilities known to the model. I.e. if one state has twice the weight of another state in the transition model from the given state, it will be twice as likely to be drawn.
        Specified by:
        weightedRandomNext in interface MarkovChain<T extends Serializable>
        Parameters:
        currentSequence - All states in this List must be known to the model, i.e., members of the set returned by allKnownStates(). Furthermore, the last state in the sequence must not be a "terminal state", that is, one known to occur only at the end(s) of sequence(s).
        Returns:
        A state chosen by weighted random draw.

      • unweightedRandomNext

        public T unweightedRandomNext(List<T> currentSequence)
        Description copied from interface: MarkovChain
        Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method chooses one state at random from the set of states that may occur next in the chain, without considering relative weights or probabilities.
        Specified by:
        unweightedRandomNext in interface MarkovChain<T extends Serializable>
        Parameters:
        currentSequence - All states in this List must be known to the model, i.e., members of the set returned by allKnownStates(). Furthermore, the last state in the sequence must not be a "terminal state", that is, one known to occur only at the end(s) of sequence(s).
        Returns:
        A state chosen by unweighted random draw.

      • hasModel

        public boolean hasModel()
        Description copied from interface: MarkovChain
        Tests whether the model has been initialized, populated, or trained with data.
        Specified by:
        hasModel in interface MarkovChain<T extends Serializable>
        Returns:
        "true" if at least one state transition is known to the model

      • addSequence

        public void addSequence(List<T> sequence)
        Given a List<T>, adds all transitions in the sequence (including transitions from sequences of lengths up to maxOrder) to the model, adding 1.0 to their weights. All states in the sequence are added to the set of "known states" which serves as the alphabet or vocabulary of possible sequences. If the input list contains only two states, only a single transition is added to the model.
        Parameters:
        sequence - a List of 2 or more "states"

      • specifyLink

        public void specifyLink(List<T> fromState,
                        T toState,
                        double weight)
        Directly specify a transition or link from a sequence of states (which could be a List containing a single state) to another state, with an arbitrary weight. This allows you to specify your model precisely, as an alternative to using the partially-automated train or addSequence methods.
        Parameters:
        fromState - a sequence of states preceding the transition. for a simple Markov chain this could be a single state wrapped in a java List
        toState - a state that may follow the sequence given by 'fromState'
        weight - the weight or (relative) probability of this transition. Weights are relative to other transitions from the same 'fromState', so they are not constrained by any need to add up to 1.

      • addPriors

        public void addPriors(Double prior)
        Adds a transition from every known model to every known state for which a link was not previously observed, with the specified weight. Since each real observation adds a weight of 1.0D, assigning a fraction here gives each of these links a chance to occur that is less than a really-observed link. Values of 0.001 to 0.01 have worked well for the author's procedural generation applications.

        Note that calling this method twice has no effect unless new states have become known. To change the priors, first call removeWeakLinks() to cull the ones previously set.

        Parameters:
        prior - the weight to be given to each new link

      • addPriors

        public void addPriors()
        A shortcut to addPriors(DEFAULT_PRIOR).

      • removeWeakLinks

        public void removeWeakLinks(Double threshold)
        This method removes transitions with frequencies below a given threshold. Its main expected use is to remove a "prior" that was previously added. Assuming the prior was less than 1, removeWeakLinks(1D) will remove all transitions created by addPriors().
        Parameters:
        threshold - the minimum weight/frequency of a transition to keep in the model

      • removeWeakLinks

        public void removeWeakLinks()
        A shortcut to removeWeakLinks(1D), this method usually serves to remove "priors" only.

      • train

        public void train(Stream<List<T>> stream)
        Trains a model on a stream of input data, essentially by calling addSequence() repeatedly, with a bit of additional logging.
        Parameters:
        stream - A stream of List<T> sequences, each of which must contain at least two states, or it will be ignored.
